nodes.text:
The hallway smells like paper and warm dust.
A door labeled RECORDS sits flush in a steel frame, the kind that assumes you’ll stop asking.
To its right: a pneumatic tube station with a yellowed instruction card.
Below a fire panel: a taped note with too many initials.
A wall placard explains faxing like it’s hazardous waste.

A note is taped below the fire panel with three layers of tape, as if one layer would be an admission.
The printed header says FIRE RESPONSE QUICK REFERENCE.
The note is mostly phone numbers and forbidden verbs:
- DO NOT RESET PANEL (unless instructed)
- DO NOT ANNOUNCE “INCIDENT” (use “irregular condition”)
- IF RECORDS ACCESS REQUIRED: notify SAFETY DESK first “for chain,” then Admin Intake “for routing.”
At the bottom: If asked why, cite “closure compliance.” Do not elaborate.
Someone added a tiny checkbox: I did not elaborate.

choices.text: (ask) Why can’t I call it an incident?
(ask) So Safety Desk can authorize Records?

nodes.text:
The note doesn’t justify itself. It just instructs.
The tape has a fingerprint pressed into it, like someone paused there and decided to comply.

The note is careful: “for chain” is not the same as approval.
It’s a promise your request will be owned by multiple people, briefly, so none of them owns it later.

A placard reads: FAX SUBMISSIONS — COMPLIANCE ACCEPTED FORMAT.
It’s mounted with screws that don’t match. That feels deliberate.
It lists requirements with the tone of a threat:
- Cover sheet must include: SITE ID, DATE, SENDER NAME, PURPOSE (ONE WORD)
- Do not use “urgent.” Use “time-bound.”
- If pages are missing, resubmit entire packet.
A final line: FAX CONFIRMATION IS NOT RECEIPT.
Someone has circled “NOT” and drawn a little arrow to nothing.

A pen mark in the margin suggests approved options: CLOSURE. INVENTORY. ROUTING.
“ROUTING” is underlined like it gets you out of explaining yourself.

In smaller print: RECORDS REQUESTS MUST BE SUBMITTED VIA ADMIN INTAKE.
Under it, a handwritten addition: FAX OK IF TUBE DOWN.
The handwriting looks annoyed, like the tube being down was taken personally.
Records is locked. I’ll route around it.

choices.text: (use) Log Records as inaccessible and proceed via tube/fire escalation language.

nodes.text:
You have enough to say, later, that you tried the obvious door first.
The hallway offers two acceptable alternatives: send the request like cargo, or escalate it like smoke.
Neither requires anyone to admit they gave you access.
The pilot light on the tube station stays steady, indifferent, as if it’s already filed you.
You step back before the building can interpret that as agreement.
